prompt: Facts: Raj Bala (deceased) was married to Inder Singh (Respondent No. 1).; Krishan (Respondent No. 2) is the brother of Inder Singh.; Bimla (Respondent No. 3) is the mother of Inder Singh.; Santosh (Respondent No. 4) is the sister of Inder Singh.; Allegations arose that soon after marriage, the accused started demanding dowry (scooter, TV, fridge) from Raj Bala and her parents.; Due to non-fulfillment of demands, Raj Bala was allegedly subjected to harassment and beatings.; On 26.05.1988, Raj Bala sustained burn injuries at her matrimonial home.; She was admitted to the hospital, and her father, Ram Kishan (PW-5), was informed.; Ram Kishan lodged an FIR alleging dowry demands and cruelty by the accused.; A dying declaration (DD) was recorded by the Duty Magistrate (PW-6) on 26.05.1988 after Dr. Kundan Lal (PW-1) certified her fitness to make a statement.; In the DD, Raj Bala stated that on the day of the incident, after demands for dowry were reiterated and refused, all four accused poured kerosene on her and set her ablaze.; Raj Bala succumbed to her burn injuries (post-mortem indicated 90-95% burns).; The Trial Court convicted all four accused under Sections 304B and 498A IPC, sentencing them to 7 years and 2 years RI respectively (concurrent).; The High Court, on appeal, acquitted all the accused, doubting the veracity of the dying declaration and citing lack of independent corroboration for dowry demands, suggesting the possibility of suicide.; The State of Haryana filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal order before the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 304B (Dowry Death), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - implicitly applied by Trial Court though not explicitly mentioned in SC judgment summary for conviction sections, relevant for multiple accused), Section 302 (Murder - often considered as alternative charge in such cases, though conviction was under 304B), Section 306 (Abetment of suicide - often raised as a defense or alternative possibility)
